citeinfo.origin: Bird Banding Laboratory, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center, Biological Resources Division, U.S. Geological Survey (USGS)
citeinfo.title: North American Bird Banding Retrieval Files

pubinfo.publish: Bird Banding Laboratory, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center, Biological Resources Division, U.S. Geological Survey (USGS)

descript.abstract: The Banding Retrieval File contains summarized records for data through the last full calendar year for all game birds banded since 1908, and for all nongame birds banded since 1954. A summary record includes all birds of the same species, age and sex, with the same status and additional information codes, banded under the same permit number, within the same region and 10-minute block of latitude and longitude, during the same month and 5-day banding period, the same band type, and band number prefix.
descript.purpose: Banding and encounter data are gathered and filed for the purpose of facilitating migratory bird research in North America. Waterfowl banding and encounter data are used by federal, state and provincial wildlife agencies in combination with other data sets, to help set federal hunting regulations. In addition, many states and provinces use banding and encounter data as a component of both game and nongame studies. Both banding and encounter data can be combined with other data for work on bird distribution, migration, survival, mortality, population size, and other demographic parameters.
descript.supplinf: The Banding Retrieval File contains over 9 million records representing over 50 million birds processed through August 1995. The file increases by approximately 1.2 million birds each year. Data are displayed in the following order: species number, region, year, permit, month, day code, status and additional information, age, sex, latitude, longitude, direction code, prefix and part of band suffix, total number of birds. A file format is included with all disks to assist the user in separating the fields. Listings have the fields separated and identified. The numerical codes in the data can be translated with the aid of the Bird Banding Manual, vol. 1 part 5 (described in the section 1.15 Cross Reference). Status code in the first column indicates that something was done to the bird upon recapture that changed the original status.

timeperd.current: Data set began to be collected about 1900 and was computerized in mid-1960's.

spdom.descgeog: Includes range of North American species. Range includes breeding, wintering and migration locations. Wintering ranges can include South America, Africa, Europe. Breeding can occur as far north as the Arctic. However, the species being studied are Nor

theme.themekey: Parameters: EARTH SCIENCE > BIOSPHERE > ZOOLOGY > BIRDS
Parameters: EARTH SCIENCE > BIOSPHERE > ECOLOGICAL DYNAMICS > ABUNDANCE

idinfo.accconst: Information may be withheld where endangered or threatened or sensitive species are involved. To protect their interests, a "Policy on Release" is included with each request, describing current limiting criteria.
idinfo.useconst: Bird Banding data maintained in the computer files have been gathered at a significant cost to the many persons and agencies who cooperate in the North American Bird Banding Program. These cooperators have certain proprietary interests in the data they produce. The person who first bands a bird has prior publication rights to any data resulting from that banding and/or subsequent encounter of that band. Information may be withheld where endangered or threatened or sensitive species are involved. To protect their interests, a "Policy on Release" is included with each request, describing current limiting criteria.

cntperp.cntorg: Office of the Associate Chief Biologist, Biological Resources Division, U.S. Geological Survey (USGS)

attracc.attraccr: Numerous edits in order to maintain high quality.

dataqual.complete: A summary record can represent from 1 to 100,000 birds. The summary records do not contain complete band number. In this program are included all game birds from 1908 and all nongame birds from 1955 to present.

method.methdesc: There are numerous, highly variable techniques in bird banding.

overview.eaover: Entity - bird Associated Attributes - species number, region, year, permit, month, day code, status and additional information, age, sex, latitude, longitude, direction code, prefix and part of band suffix, total number of birds

distinfo.distliab: No warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the Bird Banding Office Patuxent Wildlife Research Center Biological Resources Division (BRD) U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), or the Bird Banding Office of the National Wildlife Research Center (NWRC), and not indirectly though other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data. Neither the BRD, NWHC, nor the NASA Global Change Master Directory shall be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.
distinfo.custom: United States citizens should contact the Bird Banding Laboratory in Laurel, MD. Canadian citizens should contact the Bird Banding Office in Quebec, Canada. Contact information is given in section 6.1. The following information is needed to fill a data request: Justification or need for use of the data and how the data will be used. The type of data needed and format desired (paper, disk or both) which files are to be used - encounter retrieval file, banding retrieval file or both, the species, age, and sex, of interest, time period desired, the requester's name, permit number (if a bander), mailing address, daytime telephone number.
